The State Administrator shall establish a Problem Resolution Office with officers authorized to investigate taxpayer complaints and halt collection activities if deemed non-compliant with the law. Only the highest official in the relevant taxing authority can reverse such injunctions based on clear evidence, and officers cannot be penalized unless issuing manifestly unreasonable injunctions. The State Administrator can establish a Problem Resolution Office to investigate taxpayer complaints and stop collection activities if they are deemed unlawful. The authority of the State Administrators or the taxpayer to pursue legal remedies in court is not limited by this section. SEC. 53. JURISDICTION AND INTERSTATE ALLOCATION. The text discusses the allocation of revenue between states based on the destination of taxable property or services. A Federal Office of Revenue Allocation will arbitrate disputes among states regarding revenue allocation. The Administrator's determination can be reviewed in federal court under an abuse of discretion standard. The destination of taxable property or services determines revenue allocation between states. Disputes are arbitrated by a Federal Office of Revenue Allocation, reviewable in federal court under an abuse of discretion standard. Tangible personal property's destination is where it was first delivered, real property's is where it's located, and other property's is the purchaser's residence. Services' destination is where they are used, consumed, or enjoyed. Allocation of service invoices is based on time for services occurring in multiple jurisdictions. Telecommunications services are allocated based on the purchaser's residence, including telephone, telegraph, cable television, satellite, and computer services. Domestic transportation services are allocated based on the final destination of the trip within the United States, while international transportation services are allocated based on the final destination or origin. For transportation services with the final destination or origin outside the United States, 50 percent of the service amount is attributed to the US destination or origin. Financial intermediation services are allocated based on the purchaser's residence. State Tax Administrators have jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination within their state. Rents and royalties for tangible property leases are allocated based on the property's location. The destination of rent and lease payments for vehicles depends on the term length: for rentals/leases of one month or less, it's where the vehicle was delivered, and for longer terms, it's the lessee's residence. SEC. 54. Tax to be stated and charged separately. The sales tax must be charged separately from the purchase price by the vendor for taxable property or services. The vendor must provide a receipt to the purchaser with specific details including the price exclusive of tax, amount of tax paid, price inclusive of tax, tax rate, date of sale, vendor's name, and registration number. The vending machine exception exempts vending machines from the sales tax requirements if they dispense taxable property for coins or bills up to twenty dollars and sell items under ten dollars each. The State Administrator or Secretary can enter installment agreements with taxpayers to pay taxes in installments, and may compromise on amounts due. SEC. 56. ACCOUNTING. Vendors must remit taxes based on when payment is received. An election can be made to use the accrual method for reporting transactions. For bad debts under the accrual method, refer to section 11(g). SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. The exemption for non-profit trade or business is not available for taxable property or services. If gross payments exceed certain criteria in 2 of the last 4 years, the business is deemed for profit. The Internal Revenue Service is not authorized to use appropriations for certain expenses, including processing income tax returns for years prior to the repeal of the income tax. New subsections are added to Section 7801, establishing an Excise Tax Bureau and a Sales Tax Bureau within the Department of Treasury. The Sales Tax Bureau will administer the national sales tax in required states and handle related federal duties. The Office of Revenue Allocation will be located within the Sales Tax Bureau. The Secretary of the Treasury may appoint up to 5 Assistant General Counsels without following civil service laws. Modifications to federal income tax for taxable years ending June 30, 1999, include reducing dollar figures by half for calendar year taxpayers and adjusting figures for fiscal year taxpayers. The Secretary will publish tax rate schedules based on specific calculations involving the taxpayer's taxable year ending June 30, 1999. Starting January 1, 1999, the Social Security Administration will collect payroll taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 7 of the Act addresses self-employment tax rules. For revised withholding tax schedules and family consumption refund rules, refer to section 13. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define 'self-employment income' as gross payments received in a calendar year from the sale of taxable property or services, minus purchases of taxable property or services, wages paid for business purposes, unused transition amounts, and undeducted negative self-employment income from prior periods. Transition amounts for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 are calculated based on the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define 'self-employment income' as gross payments received in a calendar year from the sale of taxable property or services, minus purchases of taxable property or services, wages paid for business purposes, unused transition amounts, and undeducted negative self-employment income from prior periods. Transition amounts for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 are calculated based on the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998. Conforming amendments are made to subsections 1402(b) and 1402(c), with subsections 1402(d) et seq. being renumbered as subsections 1402(b) et seq. SEC. 8. SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS INDEXED ON SALES TAX INCLUSIVE BASIS. The amendment to the Social Security Act now includes a definition for the CPI increase percentage, based on the Consumer Price Index for specific quarters in a calendar year. The CPI increase percentage, in relation to a base quarter or cost-of-living quarter in a calendar year, is calculated as the percentage by which the Consumer Price Index for that quarter exceeds the index for the most recent prior base quarter or cost-of-living computation quarter. The national sales tax factor is determined by the sales tax rate divided by one. The national sales tax factor is calculated as the sales tax rate divided by one minus the sales tax rate. SEC. 9. COMPENSATING PAYMENTS TO CERTAIN PERSONS ON FIXED INCOME. Compensating Payment: Eligible persons receive a compensating payment if they comply with the requirements. The payment is calculated based on the qualified fixed income payment amount and the excess inflation rate. An eligible person is someone who receives Social Security benefits and qualified fixed income payments. A qualified fixed income payment is received by a beneficiary under a defined benefit plan. The qualified fixed income payment amount is determined based on specific criteria, including the type of plan or annuity contract. Payments that vary with investment performance, interest rates, or inflation are not considered qualified fixed income payments. Additionally, payments from an annuity contract entered into after June 30, 1999, or from a defined benefit plan to a beneficiary with less than 5 years of participation, do not qualify as fixed income payments. The qualified fixed income payment amount is \1/12\ of qualified fixed income payments that an eligible person is entitled to receive during the subsequent calendar year, not exceeding $5,000. The excess inflation rate is the difference between the consumer price index (all urban) during an 18-month period ending December 31, 2000, and the projected increase in the consumer price index reported in the Budget of the United States for Fiscal Year 1999. An application is required to receive compensating payments. To receive compensating payments, eligible individuals must apply as prescribed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services and provide necessary documentation. Payments will be received along with Social Security benefits, funded from the general fund. Insurers and defined benefit plan sponsors may be required to issue statements to annuitants or plan participants as needed by the Secretary to determine qualified fixed income payment amounts. SEC. 10. INTEREST. Amends section 6621 of the Internal Revenue Code by adjusting interest rates. SEC. 11. SUPERMAJORITY REQUIRED TO RAISE RATE. Prohibits any bill that increases federal sales tax rate and reduces federal revenues without a two-thirds majority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate.
